THE LATEST NEWS:
Public Notice is hereby given that His Excellency the Lieutenant Governor has been pleased to order that Sittings of the Legislative Assembly of the Province of Saskatchewan shall be held within the limits of the Town of Prince Albert, on the following days:
BATTLEFORD, Tuesday, November 6th.
PRINCE ALBERT, Tuesday, November 13th.
By Command,
Lt. Col. Gordon, Secretary.
Lieutenant Governor's Office, Regina, Oct. 2nd.

Notice is hereby given that the above lands will be sold for the balance of the taxes due thereon, viz., $25.00, on the 1st day of December next, unless sooner paid, according to the requirements of the Act of Parliament made in connection therewith by the Indian Agent.

HAFTER DEED,
Indian Officer, Regina.
Sept. 19th.

THE BAZAAR.

The Ladies Aid Society of St. Paul's Presbyterian Church took advantage of Thursday being exhibition day, and held a bazaar in aid of the church funds. The sale was a great success, and the proceeds will be used to purchase a new piano. The sale included a variety of items such as jewelry, clothing, and household goods.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

Wigmore's Clothing Sale is still going on. Good dry Goods for sale at Walker & Baker's.

Leaves, subscriptions for the Deaf, etc., are now available at James's Bookseller's.

Rice's Paint Sale, Warren's Safe Co., Kindall's Spark Cure, and Poppas at J. Jackson's.

Mr. Jackson's son is erecting a fine stable in rear of his premises on Church Street.

Mr. Chan, May appear from Monday last Sunday. Mr. Chan and family will remain at the lake for some time yet.

Mr. Wilson, who has been visiting us for several weeks, has just arrived back in town on Wednesday last.

Mr. Warren has received balance of the gold bullion of which he brought in from Montana last spring to Moses J. B. and B. Mack.

The trip was finished by the middle of August along the South Branch west from Bashico and stacking was all done by mid-week.

Mr. McCann, clerk in the I.D., was in town this week and is accompanying Mr. McCann on his tour of paying the Indians.

The annual Missionary Meeting of the Methodist Church of Prince Albert will be held on Sunday, the 21st instant, at the Wesleyan Church, 1st and 2nd.

By the new post office regulations only stamps will be taken for registration in addition to the regular rate. This will apply to both letters and packages.

There will be no service in the Methodist Church on Sunday week, the 14th inst., the parishioners of Rev. Mr. How will attend the Sunday School afternoon Missionary Meeting.

We would wish that those farmers who experience any loss by fire this year would please let us know so that we may report the result of their experiments; we would like to get the facts from our readers as to how much the yield.

As will be seen by an advertisement in another column the Mounted Police are about to receive large quantities of provisions, etc., to be delivered at the barracks here at Athabasca. This is a good chance for the farmers to send in their surplus. Tenders are also asked for, for the erection of transport sheds at the barracks here.

Mr. R. T. Goodfellow got back from Winnipeg this week.

Walker & Baker's Black Tea for 40 cents per pound is excellent in flavor and strength. We would advise you to try it.

Wigmore's Great Clearing Sale is still going on. Bargains are to be had everywhere.

On the latter trip of the party from Prince Albert, Mr. Porter and Capt. John McKay, whom he found was suffering from dropsy of the heart and lungs, were obliged to turn back when the doctor felt no improvement whatever.

The Rev. A. Peters, of Saskatoon, will preach here on the 21st and a public meeting will be held on the evening of the same day when addresses will be given regarding the work of the church in the various mission fields. A collection will be taken up for the church's use. A cordial invitation is extended.

We have great pleasure in congratulating Capt. Young on his promotion to the rank of major in the Canadian Mounted Police. Capt. Young is a native of Bathurst, New Brunswick, and has served with the 50th Regiment in the Indian mutiny and also in the Mauai rebellion in New Zealand, and is now in the capable hands of Second Expedition.

For ladies Jackson and Jermy's new line of ladies' underwear is now at Walker & Baker—they are selling at cost.

Subscribe for your newspapers as Cass's Bookseller. Subscriptions received at Walker & Baker's, the Post Office, and Foreign Publications at lowest rates.

ADVICE TO MOTHERS.

If you have a child suffering from rheumatism or your own rheumatic condition, you should take a bath of Mrs. Warren's Remedy. It is a powerful anti-rheumatic remedy. (Registered.) It contains, besides its powerful anti-rheumatic qualities, a large amount of iron and other valuable ingredients. It is recommended as a cure for rheumatism, rheumatic fever, rheumatic pains, rheumatic affections of the joints, and is the prescription of one of the best physicians in the world. Price five cents.

Butten's list at 8c per copy.
We have contracts to be made for it in NEW YORK.

FRIDAY, OCT. 5, 1888.

THE EXHIBITION
Those who have attended the annual exhibitions of the Lorne Agricultural Society during the past five or six years will have noticed a marked improvement each year; but the exhibition held this week was by far the most successful held to date, and would have been considered a fair idea of the capabilities of the district. It is very much to be regretted that owing to our distance from the railway, people from the east are unable to visit our Shows and we are unable to send delegations to examine our crops and other contents. A good exhibit of the products of a district is the best advertisement that a district could possibly have, for the reason that it is the most reliable. The exhibit of thoroughbred and grade cattle shows a great improvement over former years, there being some herds on exhibition which would take a first place anywhere in Canada. Some of our farmers have expended large sums of money in improving their stock and they should not be discouraged if, for some time, they get no adequate return. The display of roots and cereals at this show do much to show what can be done and adapted both for Agriculture and Horticulture, while the dairy products on exhibition could not be surpassed in quality. We are pleased to note the increased interest taken in the exhibition by the farmers, and others, an interest which we earnestly hope will be kept up and which will result to the advantage of the district. It is rather unfortunate that there is no building in the town in which these exhibitions can be held; the Agricultural Society should make an effort to secure land while prices are low and erect a suitable hall; we feel confident that if the matter is pressed hard little, if any, difficulty would be experienced in its accomplishment. We congratulate the Society and its officers on the great success of the exhibition. A full report will appear in our next issue.

We are happy to state that the difficulty which arose between the Town authorities and the Mounted Police owing to the arrest of the town constable by the latter and which at one time threatened to come before the courts, has been amicably and satisfactorily settled. The Mounted Police will not hereafter interfere in matters over which the town has jurisdiction unless called upon to do so, and as it is as it should be, and will tend to preserve the good feeling existing between Police and citizens.

The following Call says:
There is probably no portion of the North-West Territories so badly in want of railway facilities as the southern part of Assiniboina. During the last few years the settlers have been filling up with settlers who are doing well on the lands which they have taken up, and the result is that the grain is stored in storehouses and the flour is stored in stores. The natural facilities are favorable to success, but owing to the present lack of railway facilities, the settlers are unable to secure a ready market. They have frequently made known their wants and have anxiously looked for relief.

The above language might be more truthfully used with regard to the District of Saskatchewan; there is no portion of Canada more in need of railway facilities than this district, and the Call should know it, and no district has a better right to expect relief from the government in that respect than ours.

The Hudson Bay Railway scheme has fallen through and it is not likely that it will be revived for some time. It is to be regretted that the Company did not receive such assistance from the government of the Province of Manitoba as would have enabled them to prosecute the construction of that road to a successful and speedy end. The project of building a railway to Hudson's Bay has been regarded by many people as Utopian, but we believe that it is a question of time when the carrying trade of the North-West will be done through that route. The country may yet reach that stage of prosperity and development that would warrant the opening up of the H. B. route, but as the volume of trade increases and our exports become great, as they surely must, the necessity for that our natural outlet will become more apparent.

The coroners have had to use one of their rooms in one of their Town Hall for a prison. There are three cells all very strongly and securely fastened, but they lack the convenience of a good matress, a cell and which should be put in.

Mr. R. S. McKenzie, wife and family of Deuel were in town Monday. Mr. McKenzie's father, Mr. McKenzie, has been in Prince Albert since his arrival in the country. Mr. McKenzie was on his way to Edmonton when he fell ill and his family thought their travel money would be returned by John Smith's Reserve and pay for the doctor's services or medicines.

The friends of Mr. Porter will regret to learn of the death of his brother Albert who was a member of the telegraph department. Mr. Porter said "Ah! left Prince Albert last fall for his home in Nova Scotia where he has had poor health, but now that he is better he was better able to leave for the west where he had an appointment. Since then he was again taken ill, which resulted in his death at Woodside. We extend our sincere sympathy to the Deuel and other members of the family in their bereavement."

Depot Post Office Inspector Porter arrived by the last mail stage and has re-established a new order office. Mr. Porter has been very well pleased with the way in which the depot post master handled Mr. Way, conductor of the best train in the west. He said that this is one of the very few offices at which there is seldom, if ever, a mistake made. Mr. Porter said that he could get orders on any many order offices in the world, at rates from ten to fifty cents each, sometimes even more. A gentleman made that an person can get an order for more than $100 in one day, made in favor of the same person.

The depot post office has been made a Custom post of every office very shortly for books, parcels etc.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

CALGARY.

From the Tribune, Sept. 19.

Destructive fires are raging in the Up-
per Red River Country, Manitoba. Rains
have started, but have been turned over and the fires cannot be checked.

The Blackfoot and Stoney have been
going to the North-West Mounted Police
for help to put out these destructive
fires. Everything seems to be progressing
favorably for the Haywood House on the
coast of the 26th. The ladies are very
enthusiastic about the project and will provide all the necessary aid and
assistance. A committee will be formed
to purchase the hall with the assistance
of the local, suitable matters, extravagance,
and a general good time may be expected.

LETHBRIDGE.

From the News, Sept. 19.

The shaft for the N.W.M. & Co. Ltd
mine near Lethbridge, Alberta, has been
drilled and will be hoisted about a month
after an entrance is being worked from the
main drift.

A man named Leslie was arrested near
Lethbridge last evening with a charge of whiskey
in his possession. He had been out for
a long time and was carrying two cases
of Milwaukee beer and five five-gallon kegs of whiskey was seized.

ARNADALE MISSION.

After crossing the North Saskatchewan
River the traveller will find himself on
a flat plain, climbing the high bank of
the river by the serpentine trail, the
traveller will find himself about 200 feet
above the level of the river. After
crossing the river he will enter the
country, and after travelling about half
a mile he will come to where the trail
meets the road leading to the lake
Lake and the other to Arnadale Mis-
sion, in Montana's Reserve.

The Missionary Society of Canada and
Arnadale Mission is the largest forest
for mixed farming in the Territories. There
is section after section where it is one
unbroken forest of pine, spruce, fir,
cedar and small alder; the soil, is sandy
loam. There is lots of wood for all pur-
poses, plenty of water and excellent
pasture for cattle. It is a fine place
in a year for the farmers of the larger
settlements in the district. After a drive
of about seventeen miles the traveller
will see the mission buildings of the reserve
are seen, and about eight miles farther on
a height is found in the residence of the
late Mr. McKay, who built the present
chapel. The latter was erected about
three years ago, and, with the exception
of a very few Indians, the work was done by the Indians themselves;
it is a log building with siding on the
outside, lathed and plastered inside and
very attractive. Mr. McKay and his
son, the Rev. Mr. McKay and his
daughter and family are now preparing
for the school which they have taken to
christianize these Indians and make them
self-supporting. Miss McKay is the
school teacher and has thirty-five pupils,
all of whom are far advanced for
the short time they have had an instruct-
ing teacher. Miss McKay, A. A., says
they are taught to sew and knit. Miss
McKay has taken two first prizes for the
best teaching in all the Indian schools.

The Indians were working hard, their
good crops and their grain all stacked and
are now waiting for the thresher.

The people on the reserve are greatly
interested over a letter which appeared in
The Times about six weeks ago, which
called attention to the fact that the Indians
were not doing as much as they could
for the reserve, and the Indians were
"betting in a reckless way," and "that
it was time to encourage them to work
more for such purposes." Next week (this)
had "One Who Was Present" given
a straight account of the whole proceed-
ings and gave a full report of what was
done, for instance, told about the maga-

TOWN COUNCIL

A special meeting of the council was held on Friday evening last to consider the action of Const. Leslie, of the N.W.M.P., in interfering with the town council in the discharge of its duties. All the members were present and they decided to prosecute Leslie.

The Town Council held a regular meeting on Monday night at the Hall. Worship Mayor Blake presiding. The councillors present were: Agnew, Davis-Stewart, Donaldson, Johnston and McPhail.

COMMITTEE

A communication was received from Sept. Perry re disturbance with the town council. The committee due consideration to the council's failure to maintain order. They reminded them of the very definite instructions given by Sept. Perry in writing to Mr. B. D. Davis to perform their obligations to assist the town constable in every way to preserve the peace in the town, that they would be charged in case of Const. Leslie's actions.

J. H. Howard, secretary of the Lorne Agricultural Society, asked the council to reconsider the charter of the society. The council went into committee of the whole on this matter and after they came out reported that they had instructed the Lorne Agricultural Society from the funds of the corporation be given to them on condition that they would place an equal amount in a fund for improvement in lands and buildings in the municipality or for some other valuable purpose among expenditures to be made in 1889 or 1890.

RETIREMENT

A petition was received from H.R. Gavrin and others for improvements in the East End which was referred to the Board of Works.

The Chairman of the Board of Works presented his report after a fine deal of cross firing, in which no one was hurt, the report was adopted.

The present acting secretary of the A. Society, who had been doing good work towards the interests of the society, went on his way rejoicing when the council adjourned.

DUCK LIKE

As large, if not the largest, wedding week in this country, both sides of Tuesday night were filled with people. Parents, sons, married, to all of whom Father, eldest daughter of our colony, tenderly gave her hand. The day and evening dancing was continued and kept up. Over 300 persons took part in the festivities.

Mr. Bonomi, D. L. S., is here, but your correspondent cannot account for what business. Rumour has it that he is making some plans for the future.

By now many more reports have been going the rounds that Mr. John Macdonald would be at the clocks Sunday next and people are looking forward to such an event.

You have no doubt noticed that grain from this district has taken first prize at your exhibition. It is now being fed to the flour ground here. We are sorry to note that some of our cattle have not been exhibited.

Our mill has ceased running for three weeks to make necessary repairs made and to put in some new machinery and another effort will be made.

The many friends of the Rev. Mr. Kay, of Snake Plain, will be pleased to hear that he is recovering greatly improved and he is now recovering fast.

At the rifle range, on Saturday last, the postponed match from the regular meeting was shot off, the first prize list being the highest score of the day, and was competed by by those members who did not win a prize at the annual meeting. Other prizes were awarded for the match which wholly collected by Mr. John Stewart, who deserves great credit for encouraging the sport and for his crack shots.

The following rifles were used in the period in the order named: Const. Cameron, T. N.; Const. Taggart, Const. Maclean, J. D.; Mr. Mavor, Const. Johnston, T. N.; Mr. Johnson, J. Sinclair; J. Sanderson, T. N.; Campbell, W. H.; Hughes, H. W.; Newlands and J. Hughes. The highest score was by Hughes Match which was shot at a re-feeding target, 200 yards distance with similar scores by Const. Cameron assisted by Sheriff Hughes, was won by Sergt. Parker, who made the very good score of 75 points, thus allowing the team match against Maclean's team off in which the Saskatchewan association were third, and for the second time with a score of 74 points against 76 points for Maclean.
